best.why: Version B builds on the flood metaphor introduced earlier, defines slop with a memorable test ('If your work can be swapped...'), and introduces the essential smelting metaphor. Its rhythm—short declarative sentences, a conditional, and a concluding punch—matches the manifesto's urgent, declarative voice. It advances the argument without repeating earlier lines, setting up the movement's purpose.

worst.why: Version D merely recycles large portions of Section I verbatim, offering almost no new insight. It fails to advance the diagnosis and reads as redundant, breaking the flow of the manifesto.

must_survive_line: The slop is not the problem. The slop is the raw ore. The problem is that you have forgotten how to smelt.
